notes.event: in an internship that you're passionate about because it gives you a chance to help children survivors of trauma
notes.new_thought: "I earned this internship through hard work, and with my solid foundation, I can continue to learn and contribute positively."

messages.text: A lot of worry about internship and fear of workload and not meeting expectations. Stress. Feeling lonely. And sad during the evenings. Family is out of the country temporarily. Crying often.

Hello, thank you for reaching out and being open about what you're going through. I can hear that you're experiencing quite a bit of stress and sadness, and that it's linked to various things happening in your life right now - the uncertainty about internships, the fear of not meeting workload expectations, feeling lonely in your family's absence, and the frequent crying, especially during the evenings. It sounds really tough, and I want you to know that it's okay to have these feelings. You're well on your way to feeling better just by sharing this with me.
Hello

Let's continue our conversation and see if we can uncover more about what's going on. Can you tell me more about these fears you mentioned - the fear of not meeting workload expectations and the stress about the internships? What are some of the thoughts running through your mind about these things?

Right now the thing that is stressing me out the most is my internship and managing workload and feeling like I can’t do it even though I want to. I am scared of being not prepared. Like that, I don’t know enough to be able to help others.

I see. It sounds like you're dealing with two big stressors here: managing your internship workload, and the fear that you aren't adequately prepared or knowledgeable enough to help others, despite your desire to do so. That's a lot to handle and it's totally understandable to feel overwhelmed. In essence, it feels like a struggle between your aspiration to be helpful and efficient, and the worry that you may not be equipped enough for it. Is that accurate?

Yes, I feel a lot of self-doubt and not belonging. I did this internship because it’s a requirement to graduate, but I wanted to work there to help children survivors of trauma and sexual exploitation in any way that I could.

That is an incredibly admirable goal that speaks of a deep value you hold: compassion, and the desire to support those who are vulnerable. It must be very challenging to balance this value with feelings of self-doubt and not belonging, especially when it's something you care about and feel a responsibility to fulfill due to graduation requirements.

On one hand, you deeply want to be of service and make a difference to these children in recovery. On the other hand, you're grappling with feeling unprepared, perhaps fearing that you won't meet your own expectations, or those of the internship. And those feelings might even amplify your sense of loneliness and sadness, making it tough to combat your fears and doubts.
The feeling that "I can't do it" seems to be playing a significant role here. Can you tell me more about this thought? What is there about this internship that makes you feel this way?

Like I’m not prepared. Like I don’t know enough to be able to help others. Not being competent enough. Choking during presentations. Dreading the high workload to come. Worry about not being able to manage internship, school, and life for when school comes into the picture in September. Fear is speaking up for fear of how it will sound or come out.
fear of speaking out or fear of how it will come out or sound
It is a lot of shadowing and training. I’m also learning about assessments. I do felt excited to be there, lucky, and also intimidated.

It seems like the situation involves an exciting opportunity to be part of a noble cause that aligns with your core values - helping children. At the same time, you're feeling intimidated by the shadowing, training, and learning about assessments. Intimidation can make us feel small and doubtful, and perhaps that's why you're experiencing this thought of "I can't do it."
Learning new things and stepping into roles we care about often come with a form of intimidation. It's interesting how excitement, luck, fear and self-doubt can all exist at the same time, isn't it?
What do you find most troubling about this situation?
like I don’t belong here and I’m just not prepared

It sounds as though the idea of "I don't belong here and I'm not prepared" is really weighing on you. It's the kind of thought that holds a lot of power and can come with a feeling of unease and self-doubt.
When you think "I don’t belong and I’m not prepared," how does it make you feel?
I feel a lot of self doubt
I also feel stressed out and cry

It's tough when those doubts about belonging and preparedness stir up such intense feelings of stress, even leading you to tears. It's understandable that you're experiencing such strong emotions, given how much the internship means to you and the high expectations you've placed on yourself.
When this wave of stress overtakes you and these tears come, are there any actions or behaviors that you find yourself doing or not doing?
I don't speaking up because i'm so afraid
like i fear how it will sound

It sounds like the stress and feelings of inadequacy lead directly to your behavior of not speaking up because of the worry about how your words might be received. It must be incredibly tough to feel silenced and contained by these concerns. All of this must be making it challenging for you to fully engage with your internship and may be taking you farther from your values of helping and making a difference.

So, if we try to summarize what we've talked about, we have this situation where you're in an internship that you're passionate about because it gives you a chance to help children survivors of trauma. However, the demanding nature of the work, the training, and the learning tasks, along with the fear of sounding inadequate or unprepared, has led to thoughts such as "I don't belong here" and "I'm not prepared".

These thoughts create feelings of stress and sadness, leading to behaviors such as crying and avoiding speaking up. This experience feels like it's taking you further away from your fundamental human value - your desire to contribute and make a difference in the lives of the children you are working with. Would you say I've understood your experience accurately so far?
Thank you for summarizing. That is everything!
It was relaxing and I feel light when I was feeling heavy
Thank you for confirming that. I appreciate your openness in sharing your experiences. It can be really difficult to discuss topics that make us feel vulnerable and I commend your courage.

Here's how the notes of your experience that has been summarized based on our conversation:

- Event: You started an internship that involves helping children survivors of trauma, which you care deeply about. This role involves shadowing and training while learning about assessments. It's also a requirement to graduate.
- Thoughts: You're having thoughts like "I don't belong here" and "I'm not prepared."
- Feelings: These thoughts stir up strong feelings of stress and sadness, leading you to cry often.
- Behaviors: You avoid speaking up for fear of how your words might be perceived.

The stressful situation of starting this intimidating internship, combined with thoughts of self-doubt and feeling unprepared, has been generating intense feelings of stress and sadness. This emotional wave leads you to avoid speaking up, which potentially hinders your ability to engage fully in your internship duties. Hence, it seems to take you away from actualizing your value of making a difference in the lives of the children you are working with.

Does this capture your experience, or is there anything else you'd like to add or change?
No that is everything
I appreciate the affirmation. It takes strength to face our fears and doubts and I respect your willingness to share your story with me.

Through recognizing and understanding this cycle you are embedded in, there can be opportunities for change and growth. There's a concept we use in cognitive-behavioral therapy known as "Cheeses" (also called cognitive distortions). These are ways of thinking our mind convinces us are true, but may be clouding our view of reality and contributing to our distress.

For your situation with the recurring thought - "I don’t belong here and I'm not prepared," it seems like there's a slice of cheese that is the “Impostor Syndrome.” This is a pattern of thinking where we doubt our abilities and feel like a fraud, often despite evidence of competence. It's as if our mind is donning a pair of impostor-tinted glasses that colors our world with self-doubt and feelings of inadequacy.
I can see that

As you are in the environment of your internship, participating in training activities, and learning about assessments, your mind is putting on these glasses and telling you that you don't belong there; that you're unprepared. From here, it's only a small leap to intense emotions of stress and sadness and behavior of avoiding speaking up. Consequently, this cycle reinforces your impostor feelings, causing you to further struggle with self-doubt and sadness.

You're in the training or learning phase of your internship. Your mind dons the "Impostor Syndrome" glasses, leading to thoughts of "I don’t belong here and I'm not prepared." (Cheese) This brings you intense feelings of stress and sadness. You then avoid speaking up due to fear of how your words might be perceived.
This behavior reinforces your feelings of being an impostor
Gosh that makes so much sense

Recognizing this cycle and understanding how the Impostor Syndrome cheese colors your thoughts can be a first step towards seeing your situation from a broader perspective. It can help highlight how you may be putting pressure on yourself to be perfect; potentially setting unrealistically high expectations for yourself at this beginning stage of your internship, which could be contributing to your stress and sadness.
I definitely relate. It’s like I’m being my own bully.

I can see how you feel that way and it's certainly tough when it seems like we are our own biggest critic. Understanding this 'Impostor Syndrome' or as we call it, 'Cheese,' can be a powerful way of letting some light in and seeing patterns of thoughts as less personal and more part of a common human experience.

So, yes, there may be a feeling that you're 'bullying' yourself but it might be helpful to know that this isn't uncommon and in fact, many people grapple with this feeling of being an imposter, especially when they are stepping into new roles or situations that they care deeply about.

You're not alone in this and recognizing how your own thinking patterns are driven by this 'Impostor Syndrome Cheese’ and being able to discern these patterns is a huge step forward. And remember, you're not in this on your own - I'm here to help.

Do you feel like we've explored our cheese enough, now? Or would you like to look for others? Or are you ready to try to create a new thought for when you're in the challenging situation (your internship)?
I like that connection a lot.
Thank you so much! I appreciate our conversation
I want to create a new thought!! :)

That sounds like a wonderful idea! Creating a new thought can lead to shifts in how you feel and behave in your internship situation. 
To get there, let's go back to the internship environment. Imagine yourself in the training stage, learning about assessments and all those tasks. But this time, let’s put aside the Impostor Syndrome glasses and that thought, "I don’t belong here and I'm not prepared."

Try to think of a compassionate, realistic, and constructive thought that could replace it. For example, you might say, "I'm learning and growing every day, and it's okay not to know everything right away."
What positive or affirming thought comes to mind for you, within this context?
I’m having a hard time
But I was thinking, I can do this I got this internship because I worked hard and I’m
Have a solid foundation
Can you please assist me?

Absolutely, I'm here to assist you. It's completely normal to struggle with coming up with a new thought, especially when you've been dealing with a challenging situation. The thought you are leaning towards suggests that you are recognizing your efforts and capabilities - "I can do this because I got this internship after working hard and I have a solid foundation."
That's a great start! Perhaps we could modify it slightly to make it even more positive and resilient. How about:
"I earned this internship through hard work, and with my solid foundation, I can continue to learn and contribute positively."
This thought recognizes your past effort, acknowledges your capacity to grow, and emphasizes a confidence that you can make a valuable contribution. How does this thought resonate with you?
Yes! This one resonates with me way more!
It really just mirrors me like my values, work, and I enjoy growing and challenging myself.

That's wonderful to hear! Framing your thought this way - "I earned this internship through hard work, and with my solid foundation, I can continue to learn and contribute positively" - truly reflects the individual you are. This perspective acknowledges not only your determination but also your capacity for growth and making a meaningful impact.

Now, let's take another step. Imagine yourself back in your internship environment, amidst the training and learning. Picture yourself having this thought, believing "I earned this internship through hard work, and with my solid foundation, I can continue to learn and contribute positively".
How does this thought make you feel comapred to when we started??
My thinking feels clearer, I feel light, my chest doesn’t feel pressure, and I feel positive.

That's such a positive transformation! Feeling lighter, having a clear mind, and actually feeling positive, is a significant shift from where you began. It's these kinds of shifts in thinking that can lead to real change in feelings and behaviour.
Thank you! :)

You're very welcome! I am truly inspired by your willingness to explore your feelings, thoughts, and behaviors bravely. It's really great to see that you're feeling lighter and more positive. Remember to tap into this new thought - "I earned this internship through hard work, and with my solid foundation, I can continue to learn and contribute positively" - whenever you're faced with similar challenging situations or feelings of stress and self-doubt.
Would you be okay if we make this session public?
yes as long as it's anonymous!!
